body.section:
FANTASTIC PLASTIC
Did you know that plastics are made from oil? Plastic packaging uses only a very small amount, about 2% of all crude oil produced. Plastic bottles use less than a sixth of this.
In Britain we use about 275,000 tonnes of plastic bottles in the home every year – that works out at about 15 million bottles every day. More and more people are able to recycle their plastic bottles through schemes such as those assisted by RECOUP. Help recycle plastic bottles and conserve the use of our natural resources.
Start CollectingMore than one in three UK local authorities runs a plastic bottle collection scheme. This could be either a 'kerbside' collection (where recyclables are regularly collected from your home) or a bottle bank scheme.
All household plastic bottles, with only a few exceptions, can be collected for recycling. So that means start saving your drinks, milk, shampoo and household cleaning bottles where you have a local collection scheme.
Most plastic collection schemes only collect plastic bottles. You wouldn't put newspapers into a glass bank. Putting the wrong materials into collection banks makes recycling more difficult. Please, help make plastic bottle recycling a great success by following the instructions at collection points carefully. Any items which are not plastic bottles are removed at a later stage: for example, egg cartons; plastic car parts; ice cream tubs; toys and plastic bags. These items are made with different types of plastic (polymers) such as polystyrene and polypropylene. Different polymers have different properties; when recycled they are generally processed separately.
All household plastic bottles can be recycled except brown drink bottles, such as the bottles used to hold beer. These bottles need several types of plastic to keep the beer fresh, which makes recycling difficult. Bottles found in the garage or garden shed, such as lubricating and motor oil bottles, and bottles which have held pesticides, horticultural chemicals and other hazardous chemicals should not be collected for recycling.
Finally, don't forget to take the caps off and squash the bottles because then you can fit more in collection skips and collection vehicles. This helps to reduce costs and conserves energy.
By following the simple instructions above you can be confident that everything you deposit will be recycled. You will give the companies reprocessing collected plastic the best chance to develop technology and expand the range of products made from used plastic bottles.
Sort It Out!More and more companies are now putting a special code on the bottle labels or base of the bottle to make sorting even easier. If you see this code then you'll be doubly sure what polymer the bottle is made from.
Fantastic Plastic, RECOUP

p.font: This text gives facts and figures concerning the recycling of plastic bottles.

Many of the questions involve numbers. It is important to check exactly what the numbers refer to in the text, and if the numbers are used to refer to the same thing in the question. Don't choose 'True' simply because the same number appears in both the question and the text.
Remember that there are a number of different ways of expressing the same number. A quarter, for example, can be expressed as a fourth, one in four or 25 per cent.
As with all exercises of this kind, don't forget that some of the answers will probably be Not Given. This is not the same as FALSE.
